body:
Simcha Felder was elected to the State Senate just a few weeks ago as a Democrat, defeating a Republican incumbent for a newly drawn district in an Orthodox Jewish pocket of Brooklyn. But he promptly announced that when he got to Albany he would caucus with and mostly vote with the Republicans. 
 
Such a switch might startle or anger voters
title: Change in Party Leaning Is No Surprise to Constituents

body: A hardware store clerk who killed and dismembered an 8-year-old Brooklyn boy in 2011, stunning both the close-knit Orthodox Jewish community where they lived and the city, was sentenced Wednesday to 40 years to life in prison. Levi Aron, 37, who kidnapped Leiby Kletzky as he walked home on a summer day in Borough Park before killing him and
title: Man Who Killed and Dismembered a Lost Boy, 8, Gets 40 Years to Life

body: ON a recent Thursday night, Bianca Kosoy, the 41-year-old executive creative director at Equinox, was at a club. Not, as one might imagine, a fitness club, but its diametrical opposite. ''My best friend is Johnnie Walker,'' Ms. Kosoy said, half-joking, before pushing open the door to Beauty and Essex, a nightclub on the Lower East Side. Looking
title: UP CLOSE; She Makes Fitness Look Like Fashion

body: It was an unlovely place and its customers had many complaints: a chronic damp and musty smell, a poor selection unless one harbored a passion for Campbell's soups, exorbitant prices , a fresh deli that could be anything but and bored workers with little interest in helping shoppers.But still the Key Food in Windsor Terrace claimed a loyal
title: CITY ROOM; Outrage Over a Supermarket's Unfresh Replacement

author: Fred Siegel is a scholar in residence at St. Francis College in Brooklyn and a senior fellow at the Manhattan Institute. He is currently writing a book on the history of modern American liberalism.
body: THE GREAT INVERSION AND THE FUTURE OF THE AMERICAN CITY By Alan Ehrenhalt Illustrated. 276 pp. Alfred A. Knopf. $26.95. Ever since the surge in crime that began in the 1960s, cosmopolitan Americans have been on a quest for urbanity, looking for a metropolitan culture that had been lost to social breakdown. They sought safety in the suburbs or in
title: Trading Places

body: Levi Aron pleaded guilty on Thursday to killing Leiby Kletzky , an 8-year-old boy whose disappearance last summer from the insular Hasidic community of Borough Park, Brooklyn, transfixed New York City through a search that ended with the discovery of his dismembered remains.Mr. Aron, 36, arrived in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn wearing an orange
title: Man Pleads Guilty to Killing Brooklyn Boy Last Summer

body: DON'T let the milky Oaxaca cheese, stacks of tortillas and the cardboard crates of limes and onions fool you -- Sley Deli and Grocery is no mere bodega. That's because this Borough Park, Brooklyn, shop's signature product isn't on its shelves; it's in the freezer. Waist-high and right below the counter, Sley's standard-issue cold case holds a
title: NEIGHBORHOOD JOINT | BOROUGH PARK; An Icy Oasis Of Flavor From Mexico

body: KENSINGTON HOUSE $750,000 BROOKLYN: 562 East Seventh Street (between Ditmas Avenue and Cortelyou Road) A four-bedroom one-and-a-half-bath two-story brick house, circa 1905, with a basement, a backyard and an enclosed front porch. Mary LaRosa Lederer, brooklyn-real (917) 517-3260, brooklyn-real.com Open house Sunday, 12 to 2 p.m. TAXES: $3,300 a
title: On The Market

body: School budget cuts, rising expenses and grander ambitions for student activities have driven up the cost of sending a child to a New York City public school. Earlier this spring, SchoolBook asked parents to tell us about their school-related spending. Journalists followed up on the hundreds of responses we received, resulting in a series of reports
title: SCHOOLBOOK; For City Parents, Frustration Over Rising Cost of Public School

body: The portrait painter William Matthew Prior knew when to pretend to be untrained. In the 1820s, as a teenage apprentice, he learned meticulous academic realism. But he later opted for folk charm because it made good business sense. ''He pretty much tailors to whatever his clients wanted and could afford,'' said Jacquelyn Oak, the main curator of
title: ANTIQUES; The Discreet Charm Of a Trained Folk Artist

body: Moey's Princess Ball Melissa Levis's career as a children's performer began with a very bad hair day. Actually, several very bad hair months. Her son, Monty, a toddler, was flatly refusing shampoo. ''So,'' she said, ''I wrote a song called 'Pierre Wouldn't Wash His Hair.' '' That ballad describes a boy with hair so filthy that a bird drops a seed
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: THE bathrooms won. Last week's Metropolitan cover article, ''Putting In Their 2 Cents,'' chronicled an experiment in participatory budgeting, in which residents of each of four City Council districts decided how to spend roughly $1 million of their council member's budgets for neighborhood improvements. Voting on the proposals ended last Sunday,
title: UPDATE; The Voters Speak: Yes to Bathrooms

title: On The Market

body: ON a weeknight in mid-March, a room in the Park Slope Armory Y.M.C.A. that is frequently used for children's birthday parties was packed with tables draped in pale yellow, 99-cent-store, vinyl coverings and topped with propped-up tri-fold poster boards. About 100 people bumped and jostled their way to the snack table lined with bowls of popcorn and
title: Putting In Their 2 Cents

body: The cover article last Sunday, ''Follow the Drips of Paint,'' reported on the shifting New York City neighborhoods that attract young artists. Following are edited excerpts from nytimes.com: Upper Manhattan -- 155th Street up to the tip -- is exploding with the arts, from readings of plays in progress to arts exhibits, from a pop-up community
title: FEEDBACK; On the Trail Of Artists

body: WHEN Frank Galeano was growing up on Union Street in the 1960s, Red Hook next door had so many abandoned buildings that he and his friends used them as ''clubhouses,'' running extension cords from nearby streetlights. In Red Hook today, houses are much harder to come by. Even fixer-uppers sell for nearly $1 million -- when available at all. Yet
title: LIVING IN | RED HOOK, BROOKLYN; Outlier Near the 'Center of the Universe'

body: LAURA MacCLEERY was four months pregnant when she parked herself on the couch and started an inventory of the chemicals in her Alexandria, Va., town house. First, Ms. MacCleery, 40, a lawyer and women's health advocate, collected 70 products in a pile: things like makeup, shampoo, detergents and sink cleaners. Then she typed the names of the
title: Is It Safe To Play Yet?

body: The controversial ratings of roughly 18,000 New York City teachers released on Friday showed that teachers who were most and least successful in improving their students' test scores could be found all around -- in the poorest corners of the Bronx, like Tremont and Soundview, and in middle-class neighborhoods of Queens, like Bayside and Forest
title: Teacher Quality Widely Diffused, Ratings Indicate
